<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of connection_maximize_write_buffer:
```c
static size_t
connection_maximize_write_buffer (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; /**< a short alias */
  struct MemoryPool *const pool = connection->pool;
  void *new_buf;
  size_t new_size;
  size_t free_size;

  mhd_assert ((NULL != c->write_buffer) || (0 == c->write_buffer_size));
  mhd_assert (c->write_buffer_append_offset >= c->write_buffer_send_offset);
  mhd_assert (c->write_buffer_size >= c->write_buffer_append_offset);

  free_size = MHD_pool_get_free (pool);
  if (0 != free_size)
  {
    new_size = c->write_buffer_size + free_size;
    /* This function must not move the buffer position.
     * MHD_pool_reallocate () may return the new position only if buffer was
     * allocated 'from_end' or is not the last allocation,
     * which should not happen. */
    mhd_assert ((NULL == c->write_buffer) || \
                MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace (pool, c->write_buffer, \
                                               c->write_buffer_size));
    new_buf = MHD_pool_reallocate (pool,
                                   c->write_buffer,
                                   c->write_buffer_size,
                                   new_size);
    mhd_assert ((c->write_buffer == new_buf) || (NULL == c->write_buffer));
    c->write_buffer = new_buf;
    c->write_buffer_size = new_size;
    if (c->write_buffer_send_offset == c->write_buffer_append_offset)
    {
      /* All data have been sent, reset offsets to zero. */
      c->write_buffer_send_offset = 0;
      c->write_buffer_append_offset = 0;
    }
  }

  return c->write_buffer_size - c->write_buffer_append_offset;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
c->write_buffer = new_buf;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The single assignment c->write_buffer = new_buf; itself does not call any <string.h> functions and therefore does not directly cause out-of-bounds accesses. In this function the code updates c->write_buffer_size immediately after the assignment and contains assertions ensuring either the buffer was reallocated in-place or the previous buffer was NULL, so under correct implementation of MHD_pool_reallocate this assignment is safe. A possible violation scenario (hypothetical) would be if MHD_pool_reallocate incorrectly returned a pointer to a smaller region (or new_size were not applied) and later code used string functions (e.g. memcpy(c->write_buffer + append_offset, src, n)) where n exceeds the actual capacity — that would violate Rule 21.17.
